citations.narrative:
There were still no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the ducks,
turkeys, chickens, peacocks, and quail.
Per this Section of the Regulations, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the
acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the
animals. The Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for the birds and ensure
that the animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions.

Although the Licensee has developed and there is a Contingency Plan in place, the animal caretakers/husbandry staff
have not been trained on the Plan.
Per this Section, exhibitors must provide training for their personnel regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in
the Contingency Plan. Training of personnel on the provisions of the facility’s Contingency Plan ensures all employees are
familiar with the Plan and the animals receive proper care during emergency situations. Correct by 2/16/24.

One rabbit stood on its hindlegs and began to scratch and paw at the wire mesh front of the enclosure near the water
bottle when the inspector and facility representative approached the hutch located inside a metal frame storage shelter.
Closer examination revealed that most of the water in the bottle was frozen and the water inside the bottle's metal sipper
tube was also frozen, blocking the flow of water. The facility representative immediately offered water in a bowl to the
rabbit and the rabbit drank continuously for almost 2 minutes.
Per this Section, rabbits shall be provided with water daily. Lack of drinking water can adversely affect the health of
animals. Cold winter temperatures can cause freezing of the drinking water and limit the availability of water for the
animals. Water receptacles need to be checked regularly during cold weather to ensure the water has not frozen.
Corrected immediately at the time of the inspection. To remain corrected from this date 1/31/24 forward.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed and were provided with materials to enhance their environment, a
written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds is still under
development and has not been reviewed by the Attending Veterinarian.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were still no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the ducks, 
turkeys, chickens, peacocks, and quail. 
 
Per this Section of the Regulations, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the 
acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the 
animals. The Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for the birds and ensure 
that the animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. 
2.134(c) 
   
Contingency planning. 
Although the Licensee has developed and there is a Contingency Plan in place, the animal caretakers/husbandry staff 
have not been trained on the Plan.  
 
Per this Section, exhibitors must provide training for their personnel regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in 
the Contingency Plan. Training of personnel on the provisions of the facility’s Contingency Plan ensures all employees are 
familiar with the Plan and the animals receive proper care during emergency situations. Correct by 2/16/24. 
3.55  Direct
   
Watering. 
One rabbit stood on its hindlegs and began to scratch and paw at the wire mesh front of the enclosure near the water 
bottle when the inspector and facility representative approached the hutch located inside a metal frame storage shelter. 
Closer examination revealed that most of the water in the bottle was frozen and the water inside the bottle's metal sipper 
tube was also frozen, blocking the flow of water. The facility representative immediately offered water in a bowl to the 
rabbit and the rabbit drank continuously for almost 2 minutes.  
 
Per this Section, rabbits shall be provided with water daily. Lack of drinking water can adversely affect the health of 
animals. Cold winter temperatures can cause freezing of the drinking water and limit the availability of water for the

animals. Water receptacles need to be checked regularly during cold weather to ensure the water has not frozen. 
Corrected immediately at the time of the inspection. To remain corrected from this date 1/31/24 forward. 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed and were provided with materials to enhance their environment, a 
written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds is still under 
development and has not been reviewed by the Attending Veterinarian. 
 
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement 
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in 
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference 
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan 
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
*END OF REPORT*
